pullRequest.title: Issue 5221: Port CLI security changes from Pravega Tools to Pravega core
pullRequest.bodyText:
Change log description
Porting the changes made in the pravega tools repo (PR 75) to allow for the admin CLI to function in security enabled environments
Purpose of the change
Closes #5221
What the code does

Uses new properties from the admin-cli.properties file to determine if the command needs to be run in TLS mode or not.
The commands now when running in a TLS enabled environment have a trust-store which is used to verify and validate the server.

The protocol of the URI's, i.e., http or https , is determined based on the properties in the properties file.
The location of the trust-store file can also be mentioned as part of the properties in the properties file.


Added tests for the above functionality.

How to verify it
Build should succeed and all tests must pass.

nodes.bodyText: Nit: please, use caps for TLS and finish comments with dot . (see https://github.com/pravega/pravega/wiki/Contributing#codestyle).
Nit: extra line might be removed.

If any of the previous settings is incorrect and caught on these catch blocks, it looks like we proceed anyway creating the client, right? I suppose that the result will be a non-functional client that won't be useful for the CLI. It is an option, but just want to double check that this is the behavior we want to implement there.
Are these hardcoded values correct on any environment? I mean, the accessTokenTTLInSeconds may be ok (while it could be on a constant variable for clarity), but what about the tokenSigningKey?
Are we sure that none of these arguments can be null?
Nit: Pravega (starting with caps).
Nit: remove extra blank line.

Why this test is exactly the same as testListScopesCommand() in ControllerCommandsTest.java? The whole point of this structure would be to have the same common tests in both auth and no auth tests, which can be inherited, right? I mean, AbstractAdminCommandTest may implement the "common" tests for both auth and no auth tests. Then, if you need some specific tests on either of them, you could implement them in their respective classes. But please, do not duplicate code, as it makes maintenance harder and it provides no benefit.
All this piece of code seems repeated here and in the previous test. Wondering about if we could add this logic in a utility method in testcommon package, which I assume will be available here too.

All this logic seems similar to what is written in AbstractTlsAdminCommandTest. Is there any possibility to use the same initialization logic for both and embed such a logic in a common place, like SecureSetupUtils.java or any other place? The point is to minimize code duplication.

Many tests here are the same as in ClusterCommandsTest.java, right? If so, for the tests that are shared between ClusterCommandsTest.java and AuthEnabledControllerCommandsTest, move them to AbstractAdminCommandTest so both classes can inherit them and we can prevent code duplication. Then, the specific tests can be implemented on their respective test classes.
Nit: remove extra blank line.

These two lines repeat multiple times in this file. Please use something like the following instead:

  
    
      pravega/build.gradle
    
    
         Line 172
      in
      fc30672
    
    
    
    

        
          
           def withoutLogger = { exclude group: 'org.slf4j', module: 'slf4j-log4j12'

Use the utility we have to do this:

  
    
      pravega/common/src/main/java/io/pravega/common/util/CertificateUtils.java
    
    
         Line 89
      in
      6acd317
    
    
    
    

        
          
           public static KeyStore createTrustStore(String certFilePath) 
        
    
  


This will help us in multiple ways:

Allows us to more easily move to a different format - say from JKS to the PKCS12 format that Java uses by default now.
Allows us to add additional functionality more easily, such as supporting password-protected truststores.
Proceeding won't work I suppose. No? @anirudhkovuru what do you say?
If auth is enabled, you'll need to specify Credentials too.
The String "../../config" gets repeated many times below. Create a String constant and use it here and below.

In general, you should avoid throwing the base Exception. If you must throw, throw the specific exceptions. Here, in the tests, throwing exceptions is meaningless, so you could simplify the code a bit by adding a @SneakyThrows exception, if you will.

You seem to be using getCLIControllerConfig() multiple times. (The name of that method is misleading - it actually does a bit of processing as opposed to returning a cached value that one'd usually expect from a method having a name starting with get). You might want to call it once, store the value in a variable and reuse it.

This test is too ambitious. It tests multiple behaviors in a single test. If one behavior fails later if something is changed, it'll mask failures in other behaviors. Please refactor this into multiple tests.

nodes.bodyText: Please remove printStackTrace.

Without the additional context, it'd be very difficult to debug this issue. Please output the exception message/trace too.
Curious, why don't we add some logs to these methods too?

Some of these config names are inconsistent with the scheme we use elsewhere in Pravega. See the following:

Configuration Naming Guidelines
Existing examples

Here are the suggested changes:

controller.rest.uri -> controller.connect.rest.uri (because it is connecting to the Controller's REST URI)
controller.grpc.uri -> controller.connect.grpc.uri
security.auth.credentials.username -> controller.connect.credentials.username
security.auth.credentials.password -> controller.connect.credentials.pwd (we avoid the term password so that scanners and other tools don't get confused)
security.auth.token.signingKey -- ? (what is this for, here?)

Etc.
As for security.auth.enable (and similar items), it indicates you are enabling auth for CLI. If you are using it for specifying that auth be enabled for CLI to controller communication, the config name'd be different.
Please avoid using abbreviations like this one. A streamMgr or streamManager'd help reduce the cognitive burden on the person who reads the code. Same for sc below.
same here.

nit: The term factory is a bit abstract. A clientFactory is more precise, and eventStreamClientFactory even more so. In general, variable names should be as precise as possible (for reasons like reducing the work that a code reader needs to perform so that the person may focus more on the logic than the syntax). Here, it's not so much an issue as the factory is used right under this statement, so you may choose to leave it as-is.
